study_plan_entry.title: Security and Cooperation in Wireless Networks

free_text.Note: The course is based on a textbook: [br/]Levente Buttyan and Jean-Pierre Hubaux; Security and Cooperation in Wireless Networks; Cambridge University Press, 2007; http://secowinet.epfl.ch/
free_text.Required prior knowledge: A good knowledge of networking principles is mandatory (including Internet protocols); some background in security and cryptography is desirable but not required.
free_text.Content: Background[br/]Introduction to Cryptographic Algorithms and Protocols [br/]Game Theory for Wireless Networks[br/] [br/]Introduction[br/]1. Existing Wireless Networks [br/]2. Upcoming Wireless Networks and New Challenges [br/]3. Trust Assumptions and Adversary Models[br/][br/]Thwarting Malicious Behavior [br/]4. Naming and Addressing [br/]5. Establishment of Security Associations [br/]6. Securing Neighbor Discovery[br/]7. Secure Routing in Multi-Hop Wireless Networks [br/]8. Privacy Protection[br/][br/]Thwarting Selfish Behavior   [br/]9. Selfish Behavior at the MAC layer of CSMA/CA [br/]10. Selfishness in Packet Forwarding [br/]11. Wireless Operators in a Shared Spectrum[br/]12. Secure Protocols for Behavior Enforcement
free_text.Keywords: Wireless Networks, Security, Cooperation, Non-Cooperative Behavior, Game Theory, Mechanism Design, Sensor networks, Wireless Ad Hoc Networks, Vehicular Networks, Mesh Networks,  RFID
free_text.Learning outcomes: To understand the main challenges related to malicious and selfish behaviors in wireless networks, primarily at the MAC and network layers; the considered wireless networks include sensor, ad hoc, vehicular, mesh, and RFID networks.[br/]To be able to design mechanisms to thwart these misbehaviors.[br/]To understand the potential of cooperative behavior and the risks related to non-cooperative behavior in wireless networks.[br/][br/]Note: this course is research-oriented. The students are notably required to carry out a mini-project, in close collaboration with the researchers of LCA1. Examples of previous mini-projects can be found on the Web pages of the course; several of them have led to a publication.
